facts.text: Parties are all descendants of Durgadas Mukherjee who died leaving six sons and property recorded as Dag No. 444 Khatian No. 72 in Mauja Barasat, District 24 Parganas.
First plaintiff Saradindu is great grandson of youngest son of Durgadas; second plaintiff is grandson in another branch.
Defendants-appellants belong to other branches, specifically heirs in the line of Bama Charan, second son of Durgadas.

Property consists of 34 acres with two separate structures: eastern Bamacharan Babus Bati (commodious building, separate municipal number) and western Baitakhana Bati (admittedly joint property, own municipal number).
First plaintiff based title on conveyances from family members and purchase at execution sale of fractional interest of Bama Charan branch members.
Second plaintiff claims title by inheritance.
Defendants claimed exclusive title to eastern building: constructed by Bama Charan with own money; co-sharers gave up interest via ekramamas.
Trial court and first appellate court found no evidence that Bama Charan built eastern building with own money or was exclusive owner or that co-sharers gave up subjacent soil; High Court agreed.
High Court rejected plaintiffs' story of permissive possession by defendants over eastern building; found heirs of Bama Charan in separate possession at all material times.

First plaintiff became co-sharer with Bama Charan heirs in 1941 via kobalas (Ex. 6 series) acquiring fractional interests from descendants of Bama Charan and Shyama Charan, and auction purchase (Ex. 9a) of shares of three sons of Bama Charan in execution of award under Co-operative Societies Act.
Courts below held kobalas and sale certificate comprehensive to include all structures on plot; no exclusion of eastern building; High Court agreed.
Eastern building requisitioned by military authorities under Defence of India Act and Rules, 1939, from 1942 to 1946.
Requisition order dated May 28, 1942 under Rule 75-A, effective from 8-2-1942, served on Prakash Chandra Mukherjee as owner occupier.
Notice of award under s.19 Defence of India Act to Prokash Chandra Mukherjee for compensation Rs.125.
Notice dated June 24, 1946 for restoration of possession on July 2, 1946 to Pankaj Kumar Mukherjee and others.
Memo Ex.D forwarding cheque Rs.2100 as rent/terminal compensation to Prokash Chandra Mukherjee and others.
High Court judgment and decree dated June 26, 1964 in Appeal from Appellate Decree No. 1011 of 1962.
Plaintiffs prayed for preliminary decree for partition and appointment of commissioner for demarcation of shares.

legal_issues.text: Whether the defendants-appellants perfected their title to the eastern portion (Bamacharan Babus Bati) by adverse possession for the prescriptive period of twelve years or more.

petitioner_arguments.text: Heirs of Bama Charan including appellants acquired title by adverse possession to eastern building by exclusive separate possession for over 12 years before suit in 1955, despite 1941 sale certificate.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Art. 144 of the Limitation Act of 1908

petitioner_arguments.text: Military requisition 1942-1946 did not break continuity of possession as possession taken from defendants and restored to them; military acted on behalf of defendants.
Kobalas (Ex.6 series) and sale certificate (Ex.9a) did not include eastern two-storeyed building.
Exclusive possession not disturbed by requisition per Halsbury's Laws of England (3rd Ed., Vol.24, Art.484); Bobett v. South Eastern Railway Co.; Dagdu v. Kalu.

respondent_arguments.text: Military requisition 1942-1946 broke adverse possession; period limited to 1946-1955 (less than 12 years).
Kobalas and sale certificate included all structures on the plot.

court_reasoning.text: No evidence to support defendants' exclusive title to eastern building independent of adverse possession claim.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Conclusion of fact by lower courts not to be scrutinized.

court_reasoning.text: Kobalas and sale certificate comprehensive to include eastern building; first plaintiff acquired interest therein.
Possession by military under Rule 75-A Defence of India Rules 1939 not permissive, not as agent; independent by virtue of statutory powers; breaks adverse possession continuity.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Government possession irrespective of true owner/occupier rights; only claim to compensation.

court_reasoning.text: Agreed with High Court reliance on Karan Singh v. Bakar Ali Khan (PC): requisition/attachment possession not tackable to adverse possession.
Distinguished Halsbury/Bobett: applies to trespasser on land taken under Lands Clauses Act, not requisition context.
Distinguished Dagdu v. Kalu: court error corrected, not analogous to statutory requisition.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Litigant not prejudiced by wrong court order.

court_reasoning.text: Plaintiffs' prayer for partition includes claim for possession via demarcation.

holdings.text: Defendants did not perfect title by adverse possession due to break from military requisition 1942-1946; period post-1946 insufficient.

precedents_cited.case_name: Karan Singh v. Bakar Ali Khan
precedents_cited.relevance: Requisition/attachment possession by Collector not tackable to adverse possession claim.

precedents_cited.case_name: Bobett v. South Eastern Railway Co.
precedents_cited.relevance: Statute of Limitation applies to trespasser on land taken under Lands Clauses Act; different from requisition.
Defendant not prejudiced by erroneous court decree later reversed; not analogous.

statutes_cited.name: Limitation Act, 1908
statutes_cited.relevance: Prescriptive period of 12 years for adverse possession.

statutes_cited.name: Defence of India Act, 1939
sections: Rule 75-A of Defence of India Rules
statutes_cited.relevance: Empowered requisition of property, taking possession independently; compensation and restoration provisions break adverse possession.

statutes_cited.name: Co-operative Societies Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Basis for award leading to execution sale in 1941.

outcome.summary: Appeal against High Court decree for partition dismissed; defendants failed to prove adverse possession over eastern building due to interruption by military requisition; plaintiffs entitled to partition including their shares in all property.
outcome.relief_granted: Partition as per lower courts, including first plaintiff's shares via 1941 purchases.

key_quotes.text: The main question in this appeal is, whether the defendants-appellants perfected their title to the property in respect of which partition was claimed by the plaintiffs by adverse, possession for the prescriptive-period of twelve years or more.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: Possession by Government or the military authorities of immovable property under rule 75-A of the Defence of India Rules 1939 cannot be said to be in the character of an agent or by virtue of any implied permission from the true owner or occupier.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Key holding on why requisition breaks adverse possession.

key_quotes.text: In the result the appeal fails and is dismissed with costs.
key_quotes.speaker: court
